title: Standard Form of Hyperbola with Center $$(0,0)$$
text:
The standard form of the equation of a hyperbola with center $$(0,0)$$ and transverse axis on the x-axis is
$$ rac{x^2}{a^2}- rac{y^2}{b^2}=1$$
where
the length of the transverse axis is 2a
the coordinates of the vertices are $$(a,0),(-a,0)$$
the length of the conjugate axis is $$2b$$
the coordinates of the co-vertices are (0,b),(0,b)
the distance between the foci is 2c, where $$c^2=a^2+b^2$$
the coordinates of the foci are $$(c,0),(-c,0)$$
the equations of the asymptotes are $$y= rac{b}{a} x$$, $$y=-\left( rac{b}{a}ight) x$$
(See the left image)

The standard form of the equation of a hyperbola with center $$(0,0)$$ and transverse axis on the y-axis is
$$ rac{y^2}{a^2}- rac{x^2}{b^2}=1$$
where
the length of the transverse axis is 2a
the coordinates of the vertices are $$(0,a),(0,-a)$$
the length of the conjugate axis is $$2b$$
the coordinates of the co-vertices are $$(b,0),(-b,0)$$
the distance between the foci is 2c, where $$c^2=a^2+b^2$$
the coordinates of the foci are $$(0,c),(0,-c)$$
the equations of the asymptotes are y=(a/b)*x,y=-(a/b)*x
(See the right image)
##figure1.gif##

title: Transverse Axis
text: Which axis is transverse axis on?

title: Finding the Vertices
text: From the standard equation $$\frac{x^2}{a^2}-\frac{y^2}{b^2}=1$$, the vertices are a units away from the center of the hyperbola. What is a?
speech: From the standard equation  fraction, x squared, over, a squared,  minus, fraction, y squared, over, b squared,  is equal to 1 , the vertices are a units away from the center of the hyperbola. What is a?

title: Finding the Vertices
text: We add and subtract $$3$$ units to the center of the hyperbola along the transverse axis to find the two vertices. Given the center is $$(0,0)$$. What are the vertices?
speech: We add and subtract  3  units to the center of the hyperbola along the transverse axis to find the two vertices. Given the center is , parentheses 0 comma 0,  . What are the vertices?
